Alternate tile: I transform a normal world into a anime style and scaled world
I pondered about a couple ideas that you could add to the map, and here is what I thought of: What if you did something cool with a ravine, like maybe a mini-village that has found themselves living there. I feel like there are a lot of cool things you could do with ravines and caves, especially underwater ones. I feel not every underground structure has to be original, but you could definitely do some pretty neat things with those. I was thinking of a Tree-house village for the jungle, instead of the village being on land. Though, some parts of the village being on land and some parts of the village being in the trees would be just as cool in my opinion. I also thought for the Jungle biome, what if there were random, mossy, stone staus littered around the area? I'm not sure how to put it, but there could be a pretty good lore opportunity! I always picture stone status in jungles, sooo- I saw this idea commented on in another video, so don't give me the credit for this. Someone had the idea of a Viking-like area in the snowy biome. As if Vikings had lived there long ago, it seems. Also, watching this video makes me wonder if you're going to do anything with the End, like re-design the pillars, portal, end city, etc. Following that, it also makes me wonder if you're planning to do anything with the Nether. For example, what if u made a Piglin village in the nether, or re-designed the Nether fortress. Maybe even some original things like some save-houses, as if villagers had come to the Nether and built those in case anyone needed them.  All in all, this entire idea is absolutely stunning and I believe the finished product is going to be amazing! Your work so impressive and absolutely stunning, keep it up! (I may be editing this comment in case I get more ideas IDK)

I discovered minecraft during my primary school years. At that time, I was a really shy person. I only have a few friends, if not at all. Then, I found this youtube video about a game (Minecraft) with Taio Cruz's "Dynamite" song as its bgm (maybe some of you also knew this). From then on, I played the game and i instantly loved it. It helped me through my tough times and i made friends with a lot people along the way. I played it for so long until eventually I got busy with my other activities, so I kind of stayed away from Minecraft.   Currently, i'm in the end of my first year as a college student and seeing this video makes me very nostalgic. I really, really love this map and from the first minute, i already knew that this is gonna be epic. Thank you for unintentionally reminding me of Minecraft and I really hope that i can play your map with my old friends :)

9:41 I don't think a stone wall around a field makes much sense Most fields have/had max a meter high "walls"
8:07 to all builders watching: winding pathways make sense *only* when they match the terrain like it does here. Paths are created by walking the quickest way from point A to point B, so they're gonna round all obstacles, but if the ground is flat, the path's gonna be straight.

Hey, TrixyBlox! I have an idea for you about something you may want to try doing in this survival world! What if you terraformed the End's "Dragon Platform" into some form of mystical, draconic fortress. One that connected all the giant obisdian pillars together with and slightly ruined wall! If you made it out of a variation of Endstone, obsidian and bedrock (as well as other blocks that the dragon can't delete by flying through it) then it would make the pillars look more like they were part of this once mighty construction either made to keep the Dragon safe, or keep people safe from the Dragon.   Another thing you could do is work on the area around the major spawns in the Nether, making them sort of like a ruined civilization or something. Kinda like there was people who lived here, people from the overworld, but as time went on, their city was destroyed and they were either forced to abandon it, or just all died off, and their buildings were left to the crumbling effects of time in this harsh world.  You don't have to do my idea,s but I just thought it was cool and wanted to bring it up and hear what you think. Good luck on the build!

Like for example diamonds in the desert, emeralds in the Plains (because villagers), maybe iron or lapis in the snowy/mountain biom, etc. I think that would be awesome and help out the survival world a ton!  And what I mean by that is usually you get anywhere from between 3 & 6 diamond ore blocks  usually per each spawn spot and rarely will you get around 10 or more, I actually had a seed back in the day that gave me 13 blocks! Not even kidding I thought it was a bug or glitch but nope just really ungodly lucky RNG. But diamonds are super rare and hard to get ai having that be either exactly or close to double the normal spawn would help big time especially with animal armor mods it'd be nice to deck out my pups and kits or even donkeys in diamond armor because I could afford it lol. I have some questions, really wish to see an answers from Trixy:  1. Are you going to rebuild nether and the end? 2. Are you keeping technical part of structures and biomes, such as mob spawning (especially in structures such as pillager avanposts, nether fortresses and so on) so all vanilla mechanics are kept and working properly? 3. Are you going to introduce custom loot tables or at least use vanilla ones to fill the map with loot? 4. Are you keeping every single feature of vanila minecraft map or some things may not be included? For me the most important thing is to keep the functionality of all farms that are possible in minecraft and are based on the world generation. 5. If your map won't have all the functions of the default minecraft world, are you going to add a list of things that you CANNOT do with this map in compression to the vanilla world?  It's an enormous and ambitious project and I really like the idea of having a big custom Minecraft map for surviving. But Minecraft has a lot of different features and the technical side of the map is very important for keeping all the mechanics that we used to have in vanilla Minecraft working as they were intended by Mojang.  Ps. here are some quick answers from discord server: 2 yes, 3, possibly, 4 most likely, and 5 no Answers above are given from the discord moderator.  And for another dimentions there is a pinned answer:   - Hopefully, depending on demand, the Nether will be transformed in the area where the Ruined Portal (from the first video) leads to    - Hopefully, depending on demand, the End will be transformed where the hidden Stronghold's End Portal leads to

TLDL: Town need walls, please.       MY  ARGUMENT FOR WALLED TOWNS: Hi, as a dedicated survival or hardcore player, I would really appreciate it if world builders could fix Minecraft's biggest oversite:   any village that would want to survive the Minecraft world (a place infested with zombies) would have to have defences to survive.    towns starting with defences are more immersive, practical and more aesthetic than the players 1-day rush fencing and look more alive (while being more likely to stay alive) than towns where players just build people into their houses. not to mention protecting thems selves from creepers maintains their splendour.  the final bonus is that defended towns act as a safe haven to a player; creating an interest cure in play, in the same way, that RPG's from Deablo to Skyrim have: by creating a populated safe haven for trade from which to adventure.     DOWNSIDE TO WALLED VILLAGES IN GAMES?  well, I can only think of one, most people imagine a wall as a repeated texture or wall segment, meaning that a wall can look very boring very easily.  It takes a skilled artist to make defences aesthetically pleasing while minimizing their workload (ps love the wall around the pillager outpost).   Historically: defences were an engineering wonder, here's a link to a site going into detail about medieval curtain wall construction and the art of defence http://medievalcastles.stormthecastle.com/essays/all-about-castle-walls.htm#:~:text=Castle%20walls%20are%20also%20called,walls%20changed%20over%20the%20centuries.  long story short: please add walls or other defences to settlements!  Ty and potatoes.

What would the world look like if you combined multiple biomes together? For example combining the mesa, desert, and Savannah biomes.   The mesa would be the outskirts of the area with steep and unforgiving cliffs where a misstep could cause your demise. it would have abandoned mines/town full of bandits scattered across the land.  The desert would be the middle ground of the area only accessible by fighting through a bandit controlled stronghold that controls the only practical way to enter the desert, unless you're willing to scale the steep cliffs of the plateau or brave the old mines hoping to find one that exits into the desert. It would have small oaisis with trading towns surrounding them.  The Savannah will be the final area and is home to one of the major kingdoms, because of this fact bandit camps are rare and less populated. The kingdom would be built in and around a crater where a "unending" water flows into.

This map actually kind of makes sense. The jungle in the south creates rivers and large amounts of rain for the plains and dark forests to form. The mountain range causes them to be snowy, and a river creates enough water to form a taiga. The water eventually runs off into a savanna, which then hits the tall cliffs of the mesa, creating a desert. And the island in the south would be a natural place for things like dead animals to gather and fill the soil with nutrients. This could allow mushrooms and other fungi, protists, moss, and other similar life forms to grow in large quantities.

Great job.   Here is my suggestion for a side quest/ story line.  If you have some sort of royalty in this world you could have a Nobel villain that has been defeated in social edict and is banished to a far off corner of the map. If you read there diary you would find out that she was engaged to the prince but didn't want to marry him because she loved a cute peasant girl. So she acted like a vile bully type to get un-engaged. This backfired somewhat when she was banished from court, but she could still choose where to be banished to. So she chose the home of her love. But tragedy strikes when the prince, who came to gloat in her defeat, meets the young lady and falls in love at first sight with her.   That's the basic premise but you can write the thoughts, and feelings of the characters and what because of them. As well as events that happen before during and after the storyline.   Just remember to reward the player with an item at the end for following the quest. But that's only my suggestion.

"Once upon a time, [name of the island] was divided in 7 parts, each of them having their appropriate people : elves in the forest, dwarves and yetis sharing the mountains, dry plains inhabited by [earth savanna's animals], dragons and griffins occupied the mesa, plains housing humans/villagers. The desert had few inhabitants, only were creatures and all types of snakes, while the little island south of plains were home to monsters of the night, such as vampires or trolls.  There were many disputes in [name of the island], the perfect exemple being elves and dwarfs. Ennemies beyond time, they didn't even remembered why ! The island monster, too, were not pleased about there tiny home. By the time, dwarfs and elves fought, weakening themselves, and the monsters made plans to extend there territory.  In the meantime, the human, a weak people, grew stronger by their technologies, and their number increased. But one of their king, more ambitious, wanted more. He pitted the peoples against the others and encouraged open wars in the desert and in the forest/mountain. His goal was to conquer the elvish forest and part of the dwarvish mountains. When those people were enough weakened by fights, he invaded their lands with new war machines and tactics. Seing this stronger ennemie, the dwarfs retreated into an underground kingdom, and the elves used their magic to go underwater to rebuild their home.  While this was happening, the greatest part of the mesa inhabitants fleed to find another land, far from the evil human, and other joined elves or dwarfs. The savanna's animals tried to resist, but where crushed by the king's army. Some desert snakes who were able to live underwater went with the elves.  Yet the greedy king didn't had achieved his dream of domination. He allied with the night's monster, which happened to be a bad move. When he provided them boats to go to the desert, they backstabbed him (literally), but didn't killed him, they did worse : they turned him and his men into illagers, who now live at the plains coast, watching the island where came all their trouble."  Well, I hope you enjoyed it, fell free, if you want, to take this story, even the least part, as the backstory of your island. :) (PS : exuse me for the bad english, actually I am french!) this is what I wanted to do a number of years back, with an earlier version of World Paint (might have been a different software altogether, can't remember).... but my computer was begging for mercy at every turn. ended up settling with a very customized ATG map, letting it generate randomly. all of this, with proper configurations for mob spawns, custom NPCs and designer builds, could be *THE* ultimate Minecraft map. ....and why stop there, I'm sure if you make the call, lots of modders will jump on board to make a unique SMP server, now that there's chisels and decoration mods, there's no telling what they can pull out their asses.

Yo just 5 days ago you said this.
I've always wondered what it'd be like if there was some sort of civilization update... Which I'll explain. In short, the three current npc factions we have (piglins, pillagers, and villagers) would all have their own sort of kingdom in each Minecraft world. The catch? They're extremely rare. It'd be common for you to probably never find one for a long while in a few servers. But when they do spawn, they're big. And, the deeper you go into their territory, the bigger the settlements get, and the more frequent the smaller stuff appears. On the outskirts, you'll find the farms/outposts. Go deeper in, the roads will get longer, you'll see more stone stuff, you'll find villages, then you'll find towns, then finally cities. Remember, as you go deeper.  As you get progressively deeper into the territory, you'll notice that iron golems/ravagers/whatever the piglins have will start appearing more frequently. Same goes for any soldier types. The deeper in you go, the better equipped they'll be. Same thing goes for tradable goods. The towns and cities are going to have individuals that will give you eyes of ender as well as other rare materials like netherite... For a price. Either you slay stuff for them or give them lots of emeralds, who knows. And that's pretty much the rundown of it all.  Also, I want more ores and weapon types. For example: titanium and the ability to make stuff like iron arrows.      Thanks for listening to my TED talk

A very big tree..maybe in the middle..would be awesome i think..like the one in avater amd maybe also with small tree houses tooâ¤
looks very nice, the only and biggest problem is the base generation done in worldpainter, hear me up please, I don't want to hate, but seeing how flat those fields can get just makes your whole survival experience generic without expecting much from discovering those lands, you see, there's a very good reason why people loved the old minecraft alpha generation worlds, there's been so much height change in the terrain - you never knew what comes next few blocks in front of you, lands could go deep almost to caves and quick back to steep cliffs and huge mountains with holes and very challenging terrain. Walking across your terrain is not very satisfying from survival mode point of view as there's not much random going on - you are in almost flat plains knowing that they will probably be the same way in another 100 blocks in front of you, same goes for hills - you know there's a hill slowly shaping it's way up in front of you - you know it will probably continue to the top that way, with nothing interesting going on with the terrain. I do a lot of terraforming myself and we did an interesting experiment on one of our servers, we made a custom sakura forest biome very close to the spawn of the world - full build for survival mode (caves, materials, ores, mineshafts, rivers, survival friendly custom trees with decayable leaves, etc) and it was a very nice looking 500x500 area even without shaders and let players do whatever they wanted to with it - and funny enough most of the players chose the other directions from spawn and went for default vanilla biomes instead, even tho there was many interesting places where they could build in our custom biome. I suggest you to make sure there's always something going on every 100 blocks or so, custom builds are nice but it's not the main thing that makes your survival world interesting enough to keep you playing for hours/days.

Ideas: - a destroyed and abandoned village that got attacked by a mysterious monster in the northern snowy mountains - a giant underground beehive in the savanna  - different kinds of booby traps in the Jungle biome (made by the native villagers)  - a waterfall in the center of the Jungle - an oasis in the desert  - a lich king castle in the snowy mountains with spawners and loot - a big horror underground zombie dungeon near the infested village as the heart of the zombie swarm - a witch hut near the lake in the plains biome - a long deep chasm splitting the savanna from the taiga with many ressources on the bottom and a lot of lava (kind of like the World Scar in ARK)  - a big mineshaft in the savanna with a whole underground village (maybe a direct connection to the underground beehive and the chasm) - a giant dinosaur fossil in the desert (maybe another abandoned village underneath the fossil with many hidden skeleton spawners, kind of like a skeleton dungeon) - a glacier looking towards the ocean in the north of the snowy mountains  - a magical area in the southwest of the dark wood forest with many different colourful flower types on the ground and an entrance to an overgrown cave that leads to the Jungle  - a destroyed overgrown harbour with a lighthouse in the water (which shows the location of the ocean monument)  - a bamboo forest in the jungle with a small japanese inspired building in the middle (maybe an enchanted sword or a bow in that building)  - a giant stronghold in the northwest ocean. It should look like a castle in the middle of the ocean and have at least one very high tower (so the player can use that area to jump off with an elytra)  - a â€œdeath islandâ€œ in the northeast ocean as an arena for the wither. It should look like a dead scorched plains biome with multiple dead trees and a few wither skeletons lurking around. This area could be the boss arena of the wither - a giant luminous exotic dark overgrown cave biome right beneath the dark wood forest - the mysterious snow monster (as mentioned earlier) could live in a cave (that the player will find by reading several diaries from the abandoned village and following the clues) which could lead directly to the giant luminous cave. However, there could be even more entrances. The â€œmagic flower caveâ€œ could also lead to this biome. It would be very astonishing to find such a lively, exotic and colourful biome completely underground with very few entrances. This would also connect the story of the darkwood forest with the jungle as well as the snowy mountains. The diaries could tell stories from an underground world full with unknown dangers and flora. The player would be teased and hyped up by these diaries and would eventually find this biome beneath the zombie infected dark wood forest. It would add many layers imo. (Look up ARK Aberration if you want to see what I was thinking of) I also noticed that you donâ€˜t have any birch trees on the island. Birch wood (and emeralds maybe) could be found in that cave biome

The wide sort of building like you made is definitely more what would be constructed in a large city where it was expected that a large audience would be present for each sermon and thus extra seating in the sides would be necessary, could still be a church but not the sort that would be built in a small or try side city, since the extra width is just wasted time and resources if thereâ€™s already enough space for everyone.

My suggestion is maybe you could add a couple mods to make the game more RPG like, since the vanilla game tends to lack a lot of depth and makes custom maps not as great as they could be. The vanilla game tends to cater best to random generation and because of the random nature of the terrain generation thereâ€™s not a lot of area specific rewards to incentivize exploring the whole map and all of the best gear in the game is made to be easily achievable no matter where you are in the world. So maybe some mods with custom weapons and enemies and what not which raise the peek difficulty of the game would incentivize players to explore in order to find better loot quickly. Some areas would be harder so you could really only enter them if you have good enough loot and once youâ€™re able to survive in the area youâ€™ll gain even better loot and be able to enter even harder areas and so the game gets progressively harder but never too hard or easy!  Thereâ€™s definitely and alternative approach to do this kind of thing but it would definitely be a whole lot harder and I donâ€™t think it would end up being quite as fun but in any case Iâ€™m sure youâ€™ll find a way to make it work and Iâ€™m really excited to play the finished product!

Maybe you can add buried statues, made of ice and stone, in the tundra biome (that's what I call the snow biomes). Now, what I mean by that is make a few statues around the area, as if they were once part of a frozen kingdom, but later on got buried in the snow and ice. The kingdoms would have been destroyed, but the statues just remain. I actually got this idea from the ruined nether potrals, how they can end up being buried, but are broken and busted, and I want to see the same with the statues, only without the fire and such. The reason why I suggested something for the tundra biome is because they're actually my favorite biome in the game. They just makes me feel very calm when I'm actually in one.

A suggestion, as requested: I don't know if this would be too hard (probably would be) but are you gonna transform the Nether at all? You have that big portal in the middle - you could go through there and customize the Nether so that when people inevitably fix that portal and light it up, they'll walk into a fresh revamped nether (at least, the starting area will be unique).  This way, you could upgrade the fortress and the bastion, add a few new Nether structures (same way that you said you were gonna add custom structures to biomes that didn't already have them), and tie in the story that you're building in the overworld to the nether as well.  Obviously I realize this may not be feasible, seeing as A) I dunno how complicated it would be to sculpt terrain in the Nether like you do for the Overworld and B) it would likely add a huge amount onto an already colossal project, but nevertheless that's just my suggestion - I think it would be really cool! I donâ€™t know if youâ€™re still taking story ideas but here goes nothing:  I was thinking something similar to the Degasi from Subnautica if you have ever played it. The tale of a people that came before you as you try to track them down. You progress through the world finding abandoned bases and tribes that are devoid of all life. The more you explore the more clues you get as you find yourself in the nether to find their base there. You learn more and more about them until you are ready to fight the dragon, you enter the end following the populations path before you to find the end of their story and maybe find life in this world where you were alone. You defeat the dragon and make your way to a structure in the end, this is where it is revealed that they had all died either due to mobs, the dragon, or natural mobs.  The challenges for this idea would be enforcing the linear progression of the story, but that could be seen as an opportunity to make the story more exploration based and the whole experience open world so rather than force the players to follow the clues, they seek them out willingly.  Once again this is heavily inspired from the Degasi from Subnautica and is a very loose story that has definite room for improvement, but I had the idea of the progression based story and thought it would not hurt to pitch it

And the cave would eventually wind up at a ruined thrownroom or something, with icy and snowy walls and some cracked bricks and stone to show that it's been abandoned long ago. Almost as if a civilization once came down to the caves to worship a king of some sort, or maybe a giant dragon king that slowly died or was slain in an epic battle against hundreds of men, or just one brave hero. Maybe the dragon king once was the protector of the mountains and through humans worshipping it and doing sacrificial rituals to empower the dragon king enough to lay peace upon the land and protect its mountains against other monsters and deities. And once we explore the cave we would have to go down a long tunnel/cavern that leads down to the big cave, and we could find a massive and ginormous dragon skeleton, reminiscing of the past. Maybe it holds a secret? Perhaps it's heart can revive any that comes in contact with it in it's empowered stage? Is this how civilization once thrived near it's presence? Maybe it holds the portal to the underworld or the end. I'm not imagining the hugest of caves, cause your scale might be smaller, i don't know. I at least imagine the skeleton to be maybe half the size of the cave (depending how big the cave would be) and the cave being packed with permafrost and icy peaks and huge shards coming out of the ground and the walls, 'maybe impaling the dragons skeleton'. Or maybe have magmatic shards impale it, as if it was slain by a fire deity, or the ruler or the nether. Maybe you could have regions where sorcerers experimented in ways they shouldn't have, mutating little sections of the land with corresponding nether aspects, and vice versa with the corresponding nether, putting leaks of this world into the nether but twisted by the nether it has leaked into.;)   Perhaps having a giant base as well crafted as a consortium for this dark cult of Illagers that combined what they've studied into one massive mutated fortress.  And this would allow the creation of bases of both the Illagers and the Villagers that seek to protect the peace they seek from the evil cult.  I'm guessing that you don't intend to make mob mods, but maybe you could also have both good and evil deities crafted as statues of different types representing aspects of the world, with the evil cult having their own.  Maybe for the evil cult having statues based on the minecraft story mode's Wither Storm, maybe a more decked out Herobrine statue, an enderdragon statue, and more.  Statue ideas for Cult: 1. Wither Storm, with it broken up, with potentially tiny web like connections between its segments from its final days, but each growing on its own as the smaller parts orbit the larger central part. Likely, since it'd be larger, hints of wither bones sticking out to make it look even more bad ass. 2. Herobrine, but with armor based on the default outfit with perhaps using web or other things to represent a natural mist of power that comes from his empowered body. Perhaps wielding an upgraded diamond sword inlined with white to represent the mist power flowing into and through the metal with mist the color of his white eyes coming from his palm. 3. Blaze King, custom mob design statue of a king of the blazes, with a large central sun and floating tower rods that are held together by tendrils of smoke. 4. Magma Slime King, spread about like a blob with smaller faces spread about its form. 5. Grand Ghast, a larger ghostial form with multiple faces and tendrils, with see-through ghost faces floating from beneath its form, its eyes and mouth smoking with fire. Inspired by the mutant ghast in Minecraft Story Mode. 6. Ancient Guardian, a guardian so ancient that its paling skin has started to decay into a purple state, with more spikes to emit electricity, eye bloodshot with symbols to grant greater foresight for extending its reach with its electricity, with more fins grown for greater speed. 7. Ender Dragon, just larger and more realistic statue of it. 8. Shulker Knight, a knight formed from multiple shulkers becoming a hive mind, fusing and re-forging their shells into a form that not only allows it to strike with its armor, but also conjure multiple orbs that defy gravity to those hit like orbital weapons. 9. Phantom Overlord, a giant ancient phantom with enough power over dreams that its own body has become distorted from the multi-colored mirages floating off its form. 10. Zombie Emperor, a giant armored zombie with necromantic energies floating through and out of veins, with colors not only representing the expected normal zombies, but even the alternate versions like the Drowned, Husk, Stray, and Vex. 11. A glowing mushroom monster based on the ones that turned stone golems into the Wardens that were announced that seek out foes by sound.  Statue ideas for Villagers: 1. Iron King, a giant golem king of the iron golems, armed with gauntlets with sigils, with runes across the form in a way that resembles a royal garb. 2. Snow King, with an upper body that's more muscled, having large trees as arms with frost floating around them, with a vortex of ice beneath for traversing the ground without legs. 3. Strider Savant, a wiser multi-legged strider with the webs on it now formed like a cowl around its body like royalty. 4. Shroomlord, a giant mushroom monster that used its powers to enhance cows to grant better food for the people. 5. Command Constituent, a giant being made of command blocks, or rather made to look like such, its body made of floating fragments with glowing orbs in the center as its true energy body, or at least a statue with crystals made to resemble such a form beneath the shell that is command blocks that float around its power.  All while having Piglins and possibly Pillagers being neutral factions spread about both the normal and the nether locations with smaller bases of their own.   These are just ideas though. They were just a people that were literally from a different plane of existence. The Stonecutter is where you seem to have stopped thinking practically. You MUST remember when designing this stuff that you have to keep in mind the practicality and utility of the things you're designing. A medieval village is typically meant to be not just a place of shelter, but a place of comfort and quiet. A massive stone-smasher would disturb EVERYONE nearby every time it was used. To that end it would have been more suitable to locate the stonecutter bit of a ways outside of the villiage proper, with something nearby to act as a sound barrier. For example, a copse of tall trees, or perhaps hills. I also noticed a distinct absence of leather tanners, which would, again, be on the outskirts of town due to the noxious smell of the chemicals that tanners use. Typically tanners and smithies would be located on the eastern side of town to keep them mostly downwind of the rest of town. You should also add in a tavern or pub somewhere centrally located, perhaps near the church, as a meeting place for the villagers. And don't forget the all important warning bell for pillager raids.
